data.title: Historical Events on August 8
data.meta_description: Historical events for the 8th of August. See what famous, interesting and notable events happened throughout history on August 8.
data.text:
Events 1 - 200 of 232

Tower of Antonia destroyed by Romans

Sweden is defeated by Estonian tribes in the Battle of Lihula

Crete earthquake strikes with estimated magnitude of 8, triggering a major tsunami that damaged the Lighthouse of Alexandria and swept ships 2 miles inland in Egypt

Emperor Godaigo makes Sojiji the chief monastery of Soto Sect

Caparra Founded

Spaniard Juan Ponce de León founds Caparra the first European settlement in Puerto Rico

Emperor Krishnadeva Raya is crowned, marking the beginning of the rejuvenation of the Vijayanagara Empire in southern India

Henry II of France declares war on England and orders the siege of Boulogne

Duke of Alva's army enters Brussels, Belgium

Peace of Saint-Germain-and-Laye, more freedom for Huguenots

Uraniborg Observatory

Cornerstone laid for Tycho Brahe's observatory in Uraniborg, Denmark, when built becomes the world's most advanced research institution

John Davis enters Cumberland Sound in search of the Northwest Passage

Excommunication of Henry IV

Pope Sixtus excommunicates Henry of Navarre (Henry IV)

The city of Oulu, Finland, is founded by Charles IX of Sweden.

Galileo Demonstrates Telescope

Venetian Senate examines Galileo Galilei's telescope

Dutch expedition of Joris van Spilbergen attacks and later pillages Spanish held town of Payta, north of Lima [1]

The Irish Confederate Wars and Wars of the Three Kingdoms: Battle of Dungans Hill - English Parliamentary forces defeat Irish forces.

Dutch battle fleet of 23 ships demands surrender of NYC

Denmark & Sweden sign peace treaty

Vienna-based newspaper Wiennerisches Diarium (later called Wiener Zeitung) prints 1st edition; publishes daily for almost 320 years

1st known ascent in hot-air balloon, Bartolomeu de Gusmao (indoors)

British troops occupy & plunder Cherbourg

Jacques Balmat and Michel Paccard are 1st to climb to top of Mont Blanc, the highest mountain in Western Europe

United States One Dollar Bill

US Congress unanimously chooses the dollar as the monetary unit for the United States of America

Estates-General Convened

French King Louis XVI convenes the Estates-General, held in May 1789

The insurrection of Lyon occurs during the French Revolution.

Joseph Whidbey and George Vancouver lead an expedition to search for the Northwest Passage near Juneau, Alaska

Boston African Society establishes with 44 members

70 disciples of Gaon of Vilnius, arrive in Palestine

Peace negotiations begin in Ghent, Belgium

Bavaria joins Holy Alliance

"Stourbridge Lion" steam locomotive goes into service for the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, in Honesdale, Pennsylvania; built by Foster, Rastrick and Co. in Stourbridge, England

1829 French government of De Polignac forms

Battle of Hasselt - Dutch army drives out Belgians

Beta Theta Pi is founded in Oxford, Ohio.

Natal (in South Africa) is made a British colony

Brigham Young Leads the Mormons

Brigham Young chosen as head of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints following the death of Joseph Smith

Russian fleet appears at Nagasaki, Japan

Smith & Wesson patents metal bullet cartridges

Queen of Sandwich Islands (Hawaii) arrives in NYC

American Civil War: Tennessee's "military" Governor Andrew Johnson frees his personal slaves. Celebrated as a holiday by Tennessee African Americans (early 20th century)

Comet C/1864 N1 (Tempel) approaches within 0.0964 AUs of Earth

1864 Union troops/fleet occupy Fort Gaines, Alabama

Earthquake destroys the city of Arica, Chile

1st America's Cup: New York Yacht Club’s first defense of America’s Cup; 'Magic' (NYYC) defeats 'Cambria' (Royal Thames YC, England; finishes 8th) and 16 fellow defenders from NY Harbour to Sandy Hook Light Vessel on the Atlantic and return (38 miles)

1870 The Republic of Ploieşti, a failed Radical-Liberal rising against Domnitor Carol of Romania.

Dan O'Leacy completes 500 mile walk in 139h32m

Electric Pen

Thomas Edison is granted the patent for Autographic Printing (US Patent 180,857)

Snow falls on Lake Michigan

1st International Lawn Tennis Challenge (precursor to Davis Cup) begins at Longwood Cricket Club in Massachusetts, won 3-0 by the US over the British Isles

The US Army installs the first tricycle landing gear on the Army's Wright Flyer.

Public Law 62-5 sets the number of representatives in the United States House of Representatives at 435. The law would come into effect in 1913.

1911 The millionth patent is filed in the United States Patent Office by Francis Holton for a tubeless vehicle tire.

Richard Corfields "Camel Corps" opens "Mad Mullah" in Burao Somalia

Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition

Ernest Shackleton's ship "Endurance" leaves Plymouth, England, on the last major expedition of the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration

1914 French troops under Gen Bonneau occupy Mulhouse at Elzas

1914 Montenegro declares war on Germany

A's set AL record with 19th consecutive loss on road

World War I: The Allies launch the Hundred Days Offensive, beginning with the Battle of Amiens where 500 tanks and 10 Allied divisions attacked German lines

Treaty of Rawalpindi, British recognise Afghanistan's independence

Tigers beat Yanks 1-0 in shortest AL game, 73 minutes

Pirates set record of 46 hits in a doubleheader (against Phillies)

British-Russian trade agreement signed

1st national march of Ku Klux Klan (between 25,000 and 40,000 marchers) in Washington, D.C.

First Zeppelin Round the World Flight

German airship Graf Zeppelin begins the first round-the-world flight by airship, leaving Lakehurst, New Jersey

1929 Salem airport in Oregon dedicated

MLB St Louis Cardinals are 12 games back in NL, & go on to win pennant

Washington Senators pitcher Bobby Burke no-hits Boston Red Sox, 5-0 at Griffith Stadium, Washington D. C.

A Finnish quinella in the 3,000m steeplechase at the Berlin Olympics; Volmari Iso-Hollo beats teammate Kaarlo Tuominen in world record time (9:03.8)

1936 American Glenn Morris' decathlon total of 7,254 points is a world record; teammates Bob Clark & Jack Parker complete US sweep in the gruelling event at the Berlin Olympics

1936 Corbett National Park and Tiger Reserve founded in Uttarakhand, British India, as Hailey National Park (later renamed) - India's first National Park [1]

Bonneville Dam on Columbia River begins producing power

Great Trek Centenary Celebrations commence; the Great Trek was a migration involving Boers leaving the Cape Colony and settling in the interior of South Africa

7th Venice Film Festival

7th Venice Film Festival opens with a United States boycott due to Benito Mussolini's Fascist Italian regime

31 German aircraft shot down over England

Germany Invades the Soviet Union

German "Aufbau Ost" directive is signed by Wilhelm Keitel, to mobilize German forces in the East before the start of Operation Barbarossa and the invasion of the Soviet Union

20 divisions of Soviet 6th/12th Army surrender at Oeman

"Monty" appointed commander of British 8th Army at Alamein

1942 6 convicted Nazi saboteurs who landed in US executed in Washington, D.C.

1942 British Flower class corvette HMS Dianthus sinks U-379

1942 Soviet anti-offensive of Voronezh under Marshal Timosjenko

Common Chiefs of staff meet in Quebec

1943 US amphibians land at St Agata on North coast of Sicily

1943 Vegetables & fruit rationed in Holland

Canada/Polish troops occupy Cramesnil/Secqueville/Cintheaux/St-Aignan

1944 First test flight of the Junkers Ju 287. a proposed German Luftwaffe jet bomber; it was never fully put into production

1944 US 15th Army corps occupies Le Mans

England and Australian armed services draw the 4th Victory Test

United Nations Charter

President Harry Truman signs the United Nations Charter

1945 Soviet Union declares war against Japan in World War II and invades Manchuria the next day

Treaty of London

US, USSR, Britain and France sign Treaty of London which sets down procedures for the Nuremberg war trials of Nazi leaders

Dreyfuss family, owners of MLB Pittsburgh Pirates since 1900, sells club to Frank McKinney and John Galbreath for $25 million

1946 First flight of the Convair B-36.

1946 India agrees to give Bhutan 32 sq miles

Pakistan's National Flag is approved.

Bhutan, land of Dragon, becomes an independent monarchy

Chadwick Breaks Channel Record

Florence Chadwick swims the English Channel in a record time of 13 hours and 23 minutes [1]

Syngman Ree re-elected president of South Korea

Soviet Hydrogen Bomb

Soviet leader Georgi Malenkov reports possession of hydrogen bomb [1]

1953 US & South Korea initial a mutual security pact

26th of July Movement

Fidel Castro forms the "26th of July Movement", a Cuban vanguard revolutionary organization

1955 Geneva conference held to discuss peaceful uses of atomic energy

Fire & explosion kill 263 miners at Marcinelle, Belgium

1956 WDIQ (now KMCT) TV channel 2 in Dozier, AL (PBS) begins

USSR offers Syria economic/military aid

"Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polkadot Bikini" hits #1

1960 Charges against 53 of the 76 Africans detained after the Sharpeville massacre in South Africa are dropped

1960 South Kasai secedes from the Congo.

Ham Tigercats (CFL) beat Buff Bills (NFL) 38-21 in Hamilton, Ontario

1961 Verne Gagne beats Gene Kiniski in Minneapolis, to become NWA champ

Great Train Robbery in England, £2.6 million ($7.3 million)

1963 Kingsmen release "Louie, Louie", radio stations label it obscene

1963 Verne Gagne beats Fritz Von Erich in Amarillo, to become NWA champ

1st Rolling Stones concert in Netherlands at The Kurhaus of Scheveningen, in The Hague

1964 Dutch Opera forms in Amsterdam

South Africa Bans the Beatles

South African Broadcasting bans the playing of all Beatles songs due to John Lennon's remark that the band is "more popular than Jesus"

Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand meet to form Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)

Jarry Park is approved by Montreal Mayor Jean Drapeau for interim use by Expos

1968 Race riot in Miami, Florida

Nixon Nominated

Republican convention in Miami Beach nominates Richard Nixon for president

The Beatles are photographed by Iain MacMillan crossing the street as they walk away from EMI Recording Studios, for the cover of their "Abbey Road" album [1]

Baseball History

MLB New York Yankees honor Casey Stengel, retiring his jersey number 37; Stengel managed team from 1949-60, winning 7 World Series titles in 10 appearances

A British soldier is shot dead by the Irish Republican Army in Belfast

1971 France performs nuclear test at Mururoa Atoll

NY Yanks sign 30-year lease to play in remodeled Yankee Stadium

Spiro Agnew's Denial

US Vice President Spiro Agnew says reports he took kickbacks are "damned lies" from government contracts in Maryland. Vowed not to resign.

US President Richard Nixon announces he will resign at 12pm the next day

As a result of rainfall from Typhoon Nina, the Banqiao Dam in China fails, causing the collapse of almost 6 million buildings and 229,000 deaths

Hank Williams Jr, Falls

Hank Williams Jr. falls off the side of Ajax Peak in Montana

Chicago White Sox suit up in shorts

Maurine Stuart, ordained as Zen priest by Eido Tai Shimano Roshi

1977 Texas Rangers turn their 1st triple play (vs A's)

Pioneer-Venus 2 with 5 atmospheric probes launched toward Venus

Hussein Executes Opponents

Iraqi President Saddam Hussein executes 22 political opponents

LBV Conference Center & Club Lake Villas open

At a summit South African Trade Unions resolve to defy apartheid and labour laws

An Innocent Man

Columbia Records releases "An Innocent Man", singer-songwriter Billy Joel's ninth studio album; it featured three Billboard Top 10 hit singles: "Tell Her About It", "Uptown Girl". and the title track

1983 Jury in KC, Mo, awards TV anchorwoman Christine Craft $500,000 in sex discrimination suit against KMBC-TV (later overturned)

Coup in Guatemala

Military coup in Guatemala, Dictator and former General Efraín Ríos Montt flees

Lewis Wins 3rd Olympic Gold

Carl Lewis wins 3rd gold medal of the Los Angeles Olympics joining Kirk Baptiste and Thomas Jefferson in an American sweep of the 200m

Coutts Wins Sailing Gold

Future 5-time America's Cup winner Russell Coutts of New Zealand wins the Finn Class sailing gold medal at the Los Angeles Olympics

1984 Milwaukee 10-game losing streak ends

1984 Nawal El Moutawakel of Morocco becomes the first female Olympic champion of a Muslim nation, and the first of her country in the 400m hurdles at the Los Angeles Olympics

Baseball's new agreement permits 2 new NL teams in 1993

1985 Japan launches Planet A, a probe to Halley's comet

Altaf Hussain's address at Nishtar Park Karachi, announcing the establishment of the MQM political movement.

1986 Texas paroles American rock singer David Crosby from state prison, 5 months into his 5 year prison sentence for drug and weapons convictions; he credits the respite with helping him to break his cocaine addiction

Brewers' Rob Deer struck-out 5 times in a game

1987 Pakistan all out 708 v England at The Oval, Botham 3-217

-11] Army in Rangoon, Myanmar fires on pro-democracy students, killing thousands during the "8888 Uprising"

1988 Angola, Cuba and South Africa agree to a ceasefire in the Angolan Civil War

1988 Astronomers announce the discovery of the most distant galaxy known, 4C41.17, a cluster of stars more than 10 billion light-years away [1]

1988 Ceasefire between Iran and Iraq takes effect after 8 years of war

1988 Cubs & Phillies attempt to play 1st night game ever at Wrigley Field but are rained out in 4th inning with Chicago leading, 3-1

1988 Duchess of York gives birth to 6 lb 12 oz baby girl

1988 Jennifer Levin's parents file $25M suit against Dorrian Red Hand Bar

1988 Minnesota Twins pull 2nd triple-play of year in 6-2 win over Cleveland

Straight Outta Compton

Rap group N.W.A. release their debut studio album "Straight Outta Compton"

1988 Renovated Central Park Zoo reopens after 4 years (New York City)

1988 Russian troops begin pull out of Afghanistan after 9 years of war

1988 Temperature hits high of 88 deg F on 8/8/88 in NYC

Shultz Escapes Assassination

US Secretary of State George P. Shultz narrowly escapes an assassination attempt in Bolivia

PM David Lange Resigns

New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange resigns after 5 years on a no confidence issue

1989 US space shuttle STS-28 launched

Baltimore Orioles pull their 10th triple play (1-6-3 vs Oakland)

Baseball Record

Carlton Fisk ties Johnny Bench hitting 327 HRs as a catcher

1990 Iraq annexes Kuwait as its 19th province

Peter Rise Goes to Jail

MLB manager Pete Rose begins 5-month prison term at Marion (IL) Federal prison camp for filing false income tax returns

Gary Oldman Arrested

Actor Gary Oldman is arrested for drunk driving

Carlos Santana Pleads No Contest

Rock guitar hero Carlos Santana pleads no contest to marijuana possession charge in Houston, Texas

1991 Shi'ite Muslims release British hostage John McCarthy

Bill Preston Charged

Singer-keyboardist Billy Preston charged with exhibiting pornography to a minor

1991 The Warsaw radio mast, at one time the tallest construction ever built, collapses.

1991 With two months left, White Sox set new home attendance (2,150,951)

Bulgarian canoeist Nikolay Bukhalov completes the C-1 500 / 1,000 double winning the latter at the Barcelona Olympics

1992 Fermín Cacho wins Spain's first ever Olympic gold medal in a running event when he takes out the 1,500m at the Barcelona Games

1992 Germany goes through the field hockey competition undefeated to win gold with a 2-1 win over Australia in the men's final at the Barcelona Olympics

1992 Lou Whitaker hits his 200th career HR

James Hetfield Suffers Burns

Metallica singer and guitarist James Hetfield suffers second and third-degree burns during a pyrotechnics explosion on stage at Olympic Stadium, Montreal

1992 Spanish centre forward Kiko scores twice as the home team takes the football Olympic gold medal with a 3-2 win over Poland in front of 95,000 at Camp Nou, Barcelona

Dream Team Wins Gold

The original US 'Dream Team' wins the basketball gold at the Barcelona Olympics 117-85 over Croatia; features superstars Michael Jordan, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird, Scottie Pippen, Charles Barkley, Patrick Ewing

Tropical storm Bret ravages Venezuela, about 100 killed

Gangster's Paradise

"Gangster's Paradise" single released by Coolio (Billboard Song of the Year, 1995)

1995 10.75" (27.305 cm) of rainfall at Lockington Dam, Lockington, Ohio (state record)

1995 Jeff King of Pirates is 16th NL player to HR twice in one inning

American jazz artist Mel Tormé (70), suffers a stroke, ending his 65-year singing career

Mariners Randy Johnson strikes out 19 Chicago White Sox

1997 The UN approves a sale-price formula for Iraqi crude oil sales under the oil-for-food plan

Confederate submarine CSS H.L. Hunley is raised to the surface after 136 years on the ocean floor, off the coast of South Carolina [1]

Lawsuit Over Rocky Inspiration Settled

Actor Sylvester Stallone and former heavyweight boxing contender Chuck Wepner settle lawsuit out of court for an undisclosed sum; Wepner claims he was the inspiration for the "Rocky" movies

An EF2 tornado touches down in Kings County and Richmond County, New York State, the most powerful tornado in New York to date and the first in Brooklyn since 1889.

Russo-Georgian War: Russia launches a full-scale land, air and sea invasion of Georgia, referring to it as a 'peace enforcement' operation after Georgia responded to aggression from South Ossetian

2008 XXIX Summer Olympic Games open in Beijing, China

16 people are killed from flooding from heavy rain in Manilla, Philippines

2012 China announces that it plans to close 23 rare earth mines and up to 50 smelting companies

14 people are killed by a bomb explosion in Nangarhar, Afghanistan

2013 28 people are killed by a suicide bombing in Quetta, Pakistan

2013 4 people are killed and 4 are wounded in a shooting spree in Dallas, Texas

Previous

1

2

Next
